Problem:
Consider a linear system characterized by the differential equations set \\(\\frac{d}{dt}x(t) = Ax(t) + b\\) where A is a linear operator and b is a constant vector. An integral transformation is defined by \\( f(x) = \\int_0^T e^{At}x(t) dt \\) for a time period T.

If an initial condition \\( x_0 \\) is given and the system is evolved without any external interference, will the transformed output \\( f(x) \\) at the end of time T be the same as directly integrating \\( e^{At}x_0 \\) over the interval from 0 to T?
Explanation: The transformation \\( f(x) \\) not only depends on the initial condition but also on how the system evolves through the external vector b during the interval. Integrating \\( e^{At}x_0 \\) alone assumes no influence from b, thus leading to a different result than \\( f(x) \\), which includes the cumulative effect of b over time.
